ranked_diseases.explanation: Classic presentation with early-onset ataxia, hypotonia, and oculomotor abnormalities (strabismus). Dystonia can develop as the disease progresses.
Mitochondrial disorder presenting with ataxia, hypotonia, dystonia, and eye movement abnormalities. Age of onset and symptom combination are consistent.
Features ataxia and oculomotor dysfunction (strabismus), though dystonia is less common. Hypotonia can be present in early stages.
Can present with dystonia as a prominent feature, along with hypotonia and movement disorders. Ataxia and strabismus may develop.
Progressive disorder with hypotonia, ataxia, and dystonia. Strabismus can occur due to visual pathway involvement.
Metabolic disorder presenting with hypotonia, ataxia, and dystonia. Eye abnormalities including strabismus are common.
Leukodystrophy with hypotonia, ataxia, and abnormal eye movements. Dystonia can develop in later stages.
Neurotransmitter disorder with hypotonia, dystonia, and oculogyric crises that could manifest as strabismus. Ataxia is less prominent.
